channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Black Lives Matter Has Revealed About Small-Town America
item.description: A multiracial future has appeared, along with unprecedented conversations about race.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at the main square in downtown Chambersburg, Pa., for the Juneteenth Love Demonstration held on June 20.

item.title: Western Outbreaks Threaten Tourist Season at National Parks
item.description: Americans crave outdoor recreation more than ever. But national parks — sometimes many miles from equipped hospitals — are grappling with how to safely stay open.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most national parks have at least partially reopened, including Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona. But infections are surging in Western states that host many of the country’s most-visited parks.

item.title: Footage of Police Body Cameras Offers Devastating Account of Floyd Killing
item.description: The footage was made available by appointment at a court in Minneapolis, and shows officers seemingly more concerned with controlling George Floyd’s body than saving his life.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango, Matt Furber and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside Cup Foods in Minneapolis, where George Floyd was pinned down by a police officer on May 25.

item.title: How Steven Pinker Became a Target Over His Tweets
item.description: The outcry over free speech and race takes aim at Steven Pinker, the best-selling author and well-known scholar.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professor Steven Pinker, in his office in Cambridge, Mass., in 2018. He has been accused of racial insensitivity by people he describes as “speech police.”

item.title: Vacation in the Summer of Covid-19
item.description: Traveling during a pandemic requires lots of research, precision planning and a willingness to play by new and very stringent rules. For these writers, it still felt good to get away.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton, Christopher Solomon, Sheila Marikar and Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:credit: Eric Lipton
item.media:description: A view of the property one writer and his family rented in Searsport, Maine.

item.title: In the Same Towns, Private Schools Are Reopening While Public Schools Are Not
item.description: Private schools have always had more flexibility, and usually more money, but never has that disparity made a bigger difference than now.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller
item.media:credit: Cory Lum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Punahou School in Honolulu will be open full time in the fall. Its donors and alumni have given money to help make that happen.

item.title: North Carolina City Approves Reparations for Black Residents
item.description: The measure passed by the City Council of Asheville, N.C., would provide funding to promote homeownership and business opportunities, but stopped short of stipulating direct payments.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Susannah Kay for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asheville, which is in Western North Carolina, apologized for its participation in and sanctioning of slavery, as well as other historical injustices perpetrated against Black people, who make up about 12 percent of the city’s population.

item.title: Trump Replaces Brad Parscale as Campaign Manager, Elevating Bill Stepien
item.description: The replacement of Mr. Parscale with Mr. Stepien, who had served as deputy campaign manager, comes as the president has struggled in public and private polling.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press
item.media:description: As campaign manager for President Trump, Brad Parscale faced intense scrutiny and news coverage over the money his operation was making.

item.title: In Alabama, Can Doug Jones Fend Off Tommy Tuberville and Trump?
item.description: Mr. Tuberville, the Republicans’ new Senate nominee, will most likely repeat the same pro-Trump strategy he used to beat Jeff Sessions in the primary.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott and Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Butch Dill/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tommy Tuberville celebrated his victory over Senator Jeff Sessions in the runoff election on Tuesday in Montgomery, Ala.

item.title: Trump and Biden Square Off Over Environment
item.description: Over two days, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. laid out wildly divergent views on environmental regulations and climate change, helping to define the stakes of the presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump delivered a speech on rebuilding infrastructure at the U.P.S. Hapeville Airport Hub in Atlanta on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump’s 2016 Campaign Strategy Falters in 2020
item.description: President Trump’s political strategy worked in 2016. Now he’s in charge and Americans aren’t happy.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Rev. Vickey Gibbs, Activist in a Progressive Church, Dies at 57
item.description: Ms. Gibbs used her pulpit in Houston to treat broken parishioners in a broken social world. She died of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: John Leland

item.title: U.S. Asylum Officers Denounce Trump Proposal That Would Block Asylum Claims
item.description: The union representing federal asylum officers submitted official comments calling the Trump administration’s plan “extreme” and “draconian.”
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Migrants waiting at the border in April in Chihuahua, Mexico. Migrants have a legal right to apply for asylum in the United States once they step on U.S. soil, regardless if they crossed the border legally or illegally.

item.title: That Siberian Heat Wave? Yes, Climate Change Was a Big Factor
item.description: An analysis of recent record temperatures found that climate change made this year’s long hot spell 600 times more likely.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Yevgeny Sofroneyev\TASS, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The smoldering remains of a forest fire in the Yakutia region of Siberia in June.

item.title: 87 Face Felony Charges After Protesting Breonna Taylor’s Death
item.description: The demonstrators were arrested at the home of Kentucky’s attorney general in Louisville, where they had gathered to demand charges against the officers who killed Ms. Taylor.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin and Allyson Waller

item.title: Molly Neptune Parker, Basket Maker and Tribal Elder, Dies at 81
item.description: Ms. Parker was the matriarch of four generations of basket makers and one of the first female lieutenant governors of the Passamaquoddy Tribe.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Teenage Suspect Charged in Fatal Shooting of 8-Year-Old Girl in Atlanta
item.description: The death of Secoriea Turner has roiled Atlanta. A lawyer for the suspect said his client, who turned himself in, witnessed the shooting but did not open fire.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Alyssa Pointer/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Charmaine Turner, the mother of Secoriea Turner, at her daughter’s funeral service in Atlanta on Wednesday, with her 10- and 12-year-old sons and Secoriea’s father.

item.title: Former Manhattan Federal Prosecutor Fired by Trump to Teach at Stanford
item.description: Geoffrey S. Berman will be a visiting professor of law at Stanford Law School.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Geoffrey S. Berman, a former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, will teach a course at Stanford Law School on prosecutors and their decision-making.

item.title: Chief Vaccine Scientist Will Not Be Forced to Disclose Pharmaceutical Stocks
item.description: Dr. Moncef Slaoui, the chief adviser for the Trump administration’s coronavirus vaccine program, can remain a government contractor, thus shielding him from disclosure rules.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Moncef Slaoui, a former pharmaceutical executive, is leading the Trump administration’s effort to develop a coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Will Return to a Devastated Aviation Industry
item.description: Airlines have canceled orders for hundreds of the troubled jet because of its safety problems and the pandemic, but others are still eager to buy them.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:credit: Lindsey Wasson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Boeing 737 Max 8 taking off from Renton Municipal Airport, adjacent to the company’s 737 factory in Washington State.

item.title: Oklahoma Governor Kevin Stitt Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: Gov. Kevin Stitt said he was “pretty shocked” to become the first governor known to have contracted the virus. Oklahoma has averaged more than 640 new cases per day over the past week.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Sue Ogrocki/Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Kevin Stitt was recognized as President Donald Trump spoke during a campaign rally at the BOK Center on June 20th in Tulsa, Oklahoma.

item.title: A Heat Wave, the Coronavirus: Double Spikes of Risk Hit Communities
item.description: The South and Southwest hit record temperatures over the weekend and meteorologists warned that heat will rise in the East and High Plains.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A park in Chandler, Ariz., outside Phoenix on Tuesday. The high was 111 degrees.

item.title: Smithsonian Chief Says He Will Look Into Staff Complaint of Racism
item.description: Lonnie G. Bunch III, the Smithsonian’s secretary, responded to a letter of “outrage” from former staff members at the National Museum of African Art.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.category: National Museum of African American History and Culture
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: “There is no room for racism at the Smithsonian,” Lonnie G. Bunch III, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, said in response to a letter from former staff and board members of the National Museum of African Art.

item.title: Peter Navarro Attacks Anthony Fauci in USA Today Op-Ed
item.description: The White House has insisted there is no concerted effort to attack the government’s leading expert on infectious diseases. But Dr. Fauci called the criticism against him “bizarre.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci in May at the White House. White House officials have taken an uneven approach in responding to efforts by some in the administration to undermine Dr. Fauci, whose analysis of the coronavirus has clashed with the picture put forth by President Trump.

item.title: Scientists Accidentally Bred the Fish Version of a Liger
item.description: American paddlefish and Russian sturgeon were not supposed to be able to create hybrid offspring. Surprise!
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth
item.media:credit: Flórián Tóth
item.media:description: A “sturddlefish,” a hybrid of Russian sturgeon and American paddlefish, accidentally bred in a nursery in Hungary.

item.title: Walmart to Require Masks in Stores
item.description: The new rule, which goes into effect on Monday, is a strong statement about wearing masks in public spaces at a time when the issue has become politicized.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery
item.media:credit: Scott Olson/Getty Images
item.media:description: Customers are now required to wear masks when shopping at Walmart stores across the country.

item.title: Scientific Panel Urges That Schools Reopen
item.description: Younger children in particular are ill-served by remote learning, according to a report issued by the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Academies of the United States
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mary Kathryn Malone, with her husband, Brandon Emig, and their three children, from left, Benjamin, Molly and Patrick. “At one point, we were three full weeks behind on schoolwork,” she said.

item.title: Why You May Not Be Able to Get a Coronavirus Test in California
item.description: Wednesday: The state released new guidelines for testing that target people who have symptoms or may be part of outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: People outside a closed coronavirus testing site in Lincoln Park in Los Angeles earlier this month.

item.title: Live: Biden vs. Trump Updates
item.description: Last month, a majority of voters said they trusted President Trump over Mr. Biden to handle the economy, but a new poll shows the opposite. Mr. Trump visited Georgia as the G.O.P. turned to Senate battles there.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Victory Gardens Were More About Solidarity Than Survival
item.description: During World War II, millions of Americans grew their own vegetables, but the movement was driven much more by government and corporate messaging than by the threat of starvation.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer

item.title: Sessions Falls in Alabama, and Gideon Rises in Maine
item.description: Alabama sides with Trump, and anti-G.O.P. energy builds in Maine: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: The Legacy of the First Nuclear Bomb Test
item.description: The 75th anniversary of what’s known as the Trinity explosion, the world’s first nuclear weapon test, comes as tensions over nuclear devices intensify.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: An aerial view of the aftermath of the first atomic explosion at the Trinity test site in New Mexico in 1945. The device exploded with a power equivalent to 21,000 tons of TNT.

item.title: A Different Cold War
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
